instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SSD_PWR_EN: What is SSD_PWR_EN? SSD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip making the power rail for the SSD to turn on when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting SSD (liquid damage)
threads.message:
Hi guys!

Long time lurker

Anyways, I had a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> come in with liquid damage. Most of the damage looked like it was around thunderbolt related stuff. Went through the ultrasonic, fired right up... no SSD detected. Tested the SSD externally on my iMac and it works fine.

Checked <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>
Pin 1: 3.4V
Pin 2: 0.1v
Pin 3: 0.1v
Pin 4: 3.3v
Pin 5: Ground
Pin 6: 0.1v
Pin 7: 0v
Pin 8: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FLT</SIGNAL> I get 3.3v


Things I replaced already... I started getting desperate.
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>
<RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C3740</CAPACITOR>
<CHIP>U3711</CHIP>
<CHIP>U3710</CHIP>
<CHIP>U8070</CHIP>

Both <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> that are low appear to come from the CPU... which kind of worries me :(

I'm not in front of the board anymore for the night but I will take any advice on where to go tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting SSD (liquid damage)
threads.message:
You may have corroded/broken traces around <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>.
If <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL> is present, you MUST have aprox 1V at pin 2/<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>.
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP> can also be bad, as you cannot have 0V at pins 6, 7, 8 at the same time; look at internal diagram.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting SSD (liquid damage)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44195"]You may have corroded/broken traces around <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>.
If <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL> is present, you MUST have aprox 1V at pin 2/<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>.
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP> can also be bad, as you cannot have 0V at pins 6, 7, 8 at the same time; look at internal diagram.
[/QUOTE]

<RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> Pin 1 is 3.3v, pin 2 is 0.1v... even with <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> removed. <RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> are measuring ok. I see <RESISTOR>R3740</RESISTOR> on the schematic and it doesn't say NOSTUFF but I don't have it on my board.. it wasn't there in my before photos. I don't have another one of these boards to see if that part should be there or not... but it's the same thing on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, missing but on the schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting SSD (liquid damage)
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> Pin 1 is 3.3v, pin 2 is 0.1v... even with <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> removed. <RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> are measuring ok"
A simple calculation will show you aprox 1V as result.
Also good <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> cannot drop that voltage.
So clean the board, change the resistors.

"I see <RESISTOR>R3740</RESISTOR> on the schematic and it doesn't say NOSTUFF but I don't have it on my board"
As per schematic, there are some components marked "<SIGNAL>SSD_CLK_REQ</SIGNAL> : UNI/BI".
I hope you understand what that means.

BTW, do NOT quote an entire post from few cm above...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting SSD (liquid damage)
threads.message: Ok so checked <RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> again and the values just kept bouncing up and down super low sometimes way too high, but mostly low. I removed <RESISTOR>R5580</RESISTOR> and then the values jumped to what you would expect and stayed there. I left for the night but I'll have to look into this Tomorrow...
